loans.name: Ma. Violeta

texts.en: Ma. Violeta is 41-years old single and supports her family by operating two business ventures:  general store and personal collection businesses.  She lives in Toledo City, Cebu. Ma. Violeta joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 14 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Violeta has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,300, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 15th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to buy stocks for the general store so that she could continue to save up for the future improvement of her business. Ma. Violeta is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team - http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines - on Kiva.org to join our team.

The couple is blessed with five children, three of whom are single, and two are married. They have two kids who are employed in different jobs, and they always share their profits to help cover the family’s daily expenses. This rice harvesting season Ngan S. needs capital to purchase many sacks of rice to store for selling when the price increases.

Her husband has been earning a living for many years by climbing the palm trees behind his house. On average, Sam C.’s husband could earn a profit from this business of around $2 each day. Currently, some materials which he uses for climbing palm trees have broken down from extensive use. To help her husband’s business, Sam C. will use her loan to buy ladders for her husband, some containers for storing palm juice, and other required equipment.

loans.use: Purchase ladders, juice containers, and other required equipment

loans.name: Akbermet's Group

texts.en:
Akbermet A. is the treasurer of this group. She is a resident of Kadamjai, a small town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 24 and married to a private entrepreneur. Together they are bringing up two daughters who are preschool age (under seven). A year ago with the initial investment of 50,000 soms Akbermet started the wholesale trade of men’s and women’s clothing. She earns 8,000 soms per month. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase festival clothes to sell. In the future Akbermet wants to increase the turnover of her business and build her own store.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: Purchase festival clothes

texts.en:

In order to earn additional money she breeds livestock.  She makes an additional 3,000 KGS per month reselling livestock animals after fattening.  With money received from the loan Nasipa wants to purchase goats for breeding.  In the near future she plans to start building a new shed for livestock.

loans.name: Vân

texts.en: Vân N. has been a farming businesswoman for a long time. She lives in the province of the Kompong Cham province. Since 1979, she has owned and operated her farm to cultivate a rice crop, from which she earns a daily income. Her husband, Thim Than, is a 50-year-old farmer who helps her in the same business, and the daily revenue which he can make is about $1 a day. This is the time for preparing the dry-season rice-field, but her old cow is not able to help with the plowing process. So Vân N. has decided to ask for a Kiva loan to buy a new cow in order to replace the old one. With the remainder of the funds she will plant peanuts.

loans.use: To buy a new cow to replace the old one, and to plant peanuts.

In order to earn money to cover family expenses Lalihan and her husband breed livestock. Reselling livestock animals after fattening, the family earns an average of $106 per month. With money received from the loan Lalihan wants to purchase five goats for breeding. 

In the future she wants to increase the number of livestock and provide her children with a good education.

Because selling mortar is the main source of revenue for the whole family, Eng U. would like a loan to purchase more mortar for selling. He plans to use the rest of his loan to add to his savings to buy a secondhand motorcycle for picking up the mortar for his regular customers when they place an order.

Battsetseg is 32 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Suhbaatar district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house within his parents' fence. Her oldest son attends a primary school while her youngest daughter is handicapped. 

She and her husband operate family businesses that include a grocery shop and an internet service center. They opened their grocery shop in 2008, and after years of successful operation, they were able to open an internet center with fourteen computers and a Canon printer in the next room of their shop. They have found success in both of their businesses and purchased the printer with profits from their previous loan. 

Battsetseg is a talented business woman and says, "All I wish is for my daughter to become healthy." She is requesting a 2,200,000 MNT loan in order to purchase three computers for her internet center.

loans.use: To purchase three computers

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce N. T. is a 58 year old lady. She is a widow and has been blessed with three children. She has been in the transport sector for the last one year by the use of a motorbike and she also owns a food kiosk which is her secondary business. 

This will be her second loan from KADET LTD which she plans to use to purchase flour, cooking oil, rice and cereals into her food kiosk business. She plans to re-invest the profit into her business. 

Her dreams and hopes are to succeed through KADET loans.

loans.use: purchase flour, cooking oil, rice and cereals into her food kiosk business

loans.name: Munhtsetseg

texts.en:
Munhtsetseg is 27 years old and lives with her mother in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in the Han-Uul district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She operates a dairy products trading business to support her family. She sells a variety of dairy products such as milk, yogurt, and fermented milk, etc. out of a rented stall at the trade center in her district. 

She started her business in 2006 selling dairy products from her home, and since then her business has improved and she has gained much experience. Previously, she obtained loan of 500,000 MNT from our bank to support her business. 

Munhtsetseg says, "All I want is to have my own store in the future." She will use this loan to increase her working capital for her dairy trading business. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase and preserve more dairy products, such as dried curd, melted butter, grease, etc. to sell for the upcoming Tsagaan Sar, the Mongolian new year holiday.

loans.use: To purchase and preserve more dairy products to sell

loans.name: Dong

texts.en:
Dong M. is a sewing worker in the province of Kompong Chhnang. She has been working in this sector for a year. She has a life partner in her husband who is good at making baskets. He sells them in various places, earning a profit of about $2.50 each day. This couple is blessed with two children, and they don’t go to school yet because they are still too young. 

Recently, Dong M.’s husband ran out of essential materials from his stock supply, and he hopes to acquire more raw materials to continue making baskets. Dong M. will use her loan to help her husband buy more necessary materials in order to continue making his baskets for sale.

loans.use: To buy more essential materials in order to make baskets for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo M. is a 40-year-old married woman and a local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Tom Province. She and her husband are local farmers, and they have six children, one of whom is married.

Keo owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents upon which she grows rice. Because her crops are not growing well due to a lack of fertilizers, she is requesting a loan to buy many sacks of fertilizers to remedy the situation.

loans.use: To buy sacks of fertilizer for her rice crop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase materials necessary things for her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To enlarge his bookstore

loans.name: Som

texts.en: Som K. is a 31-year-old married woman and mother. She lives in her own small family home in Kompong Tom province. Som K. owns a piece of land that she inherited from her grandmother. She can grow rice crops in both rainy and dry seasons. Presently, Som K. is growing a rice crop for the dry season field, but it is not growing well. Therefore, Som K. would like a loan to purchase many sacks of fertilizer for her crop.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy necessary items for her son's bakery

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 35-year-old married man living with his wife and two young children who attend school. He is from Lebanon. He has specialized in baking bread and pastry for 10 years and in 2005, he decided to open a small bakery. He is the only income source of the family.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to do some maintenance on the oven and repaint it so he can proceed with his baking work properly.

loans.use: To do some maintenance on the oven and repaint it

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 22-year-old single man living with his parents and three siblings. He is from Lebanon. He helps his father and brothers to retain a good income source for the family. He has worked as a paving agent from 5 years ago and in 2007, he started to work as a freelance paving agent, sticking with several construction projects. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase more tools for his business. He needs to be prepared to satisfy the client and make a good business reputation. In the future, he hopes to expand his business operation.

loans.use: To purchase more tools

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 22-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents. He helps his father with the family’s income. This young man opened a barber shop in 2002 in his town. Because of his good business reputation, he was able to build a good number of customers who are very satisfied with his work. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to remodel his shop’s decor to attract more customers and then increase his revenue.

loans.use: To renew his shop’s decorations

loans.name: Duth

texts.en:
The woman in the photo is Duth K., age 45, who lives in the province of Kompong Tom. A married woman who is devoted to her three single children, all living at home, Duth has a few farms that she inherited from her grandmother. Her husband assists her in the farming.

She planted a rice crop over three month ago, but it is not growing well because it needs more fertilizer. To solve this situation, Duth is requesting a loan to buy two sacks of fertilizer and to hire a machine to plow the rest of her farmland.

loans.use: To buy two sacks of fertilizer and to hire a plowing machine to plow the rest of her farmland.

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en:
Hanan O. is the mother of two daughters and four sons. Hanan's son, who is studying in the university and who helps his mother in the store, appears in the picture here, as she is a religious woman like most of Gaza Strip’s citizens.

Hanan and her husband and children, who are students, live in Rafah in Gaza Strip. Her husband owns a grocery shop. The store is the only source of income for the family; therefore, Hanan and her husband want to improve it and sell a larger variety of goods to attract more customers. That is why she is requesting a loan from FATEN.

loans.use: To purchase a large variety of goods for her store

loans.name: Saad

texts.ar:
سعد في عمر 32 سنة متزوج وله اربع اولاد يعمل في محل لبيع المعجنات (والمناقيش) له في عمله 9 سنوات يحب عمله
ويتقنه جيد يريد ان يتطور في عمله وان يصبح مالك اكثر من محل لأنه طموح لكنه يعاني من صعوبةمادية لأنه يلقى
منافسة وقد ساهم القرض السابق في تحسين وضع عمله يريد قرض من المجموعة بهدف شراء طحين ومازوت للفرن يتميز بالصدق 
والنظافة في العمل
texts.en: Saad is a 32-year-old husband and father of four who has 9 years of experience working at a shop that sells pot pies and fateera pies. Saad’s work is marked by straightforwardness and cleanliness, and he himself is driven to eventually become the owner of a chain of such shops. Nevertheless, this is financially difficult because of his competition. Saad’s last loan from Al Majmoua helped to improve his business and accordingly he is now seeking another loan to purchase flour and fuE. for his oven.

loans.use: To purchase flour and fuel for oven

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 45-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and three young children who attend school. He is the only income provider of the family. He has owned a car repair shop in his town since 1990. He specializes in repairing a car’s body and painting. Over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to satisfy the needs of his family.

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase needed machinery and tools to serve his damaged client’s cars in a faster way.

loans.use: To purchase machinery and tools

loans.name: Gideon Olando

texts.en:
Gideon Olando J. is fifty years old, married and a father of five children, they live in Pangani in Kitale town, he operates a retail shop in the same area, and he has been in this business for six years now and he gets a monthly income of ten thousand shillings.

This will be Gideon's second loan with KADET LTD, he repaid previous loan successfully, and he plans to use the entire loan to add stock in his shop like buy five bags of sugar worth Kshs.18,340, two bags of rice worth Kshs. 6,600, eight bundles of flour worth Kshs. 5,760, six cartons of cooking fat worth Kshs. 7,800,transport worth Kshs. 9500 etc. With the income he will get he plans to add more stock to the business. In the future Gideon wants to be a wholesaler, and also to educate his children to the highest level.

loans.use: To add stock buy sugar, rice, cooking fat etc

loans.name: Khoem

texts.en: Making baskets is a part of 46-year-old Khoem T.’s daily routine. She and her husband currently buy raw materials to make baskets to sell at their home. They also buy baskets from other weavers at a reasonable price and resell them to gain extra profit. They have been operating this business since 1985. Khoem T. is the mother of two children; one is employed as a garment worker in Kompong Chhnang province and the other is a student. Khoem T. will be using her loan to add to her personal savings to purchase some pieces of wood to repair her old house.

loans.use: to purchase some wood to repair her old house

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 49-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and one young child who is attending school. He has been working as a freelance construction agent since 1992. He is the only income source in his family. He works closely with some contractors. He is very positive about his future and hopes to take more profitable construction projects. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase an air compressor and a crane to expand his business operation, allowing him to increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase an air compressor and a crane

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long V., age 50, is married with three children; two are married and one attends school. She is a local farmer as well as a domestic rice trader who owns a rice hulling machine inside her home. She provides a rice milling service to her neighbors for a fee. Her husband works with her in the business. Long V. usually generates around $3 profit per day to meet her family's needs. The harvest season is coming and she always gets orders from her clients to mill their rice; however, her old hulling machine is getting old and it often breaks while providing service. To solve this problem, Long V. would like to request a loan from Kiva to buy a new hulling machine to replace the old one.

loans.use: to buy a new hulling machine to replace the old one

loans.name: Stephen Wachira

texts.en:
Stephen has practiced dairy farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 22 years.  He is 43 years old, married to Mary Mumbi and they have three children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers and this will be his firth loan.  He has serviced his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy a heifer for dairy farming.

In future, Stephen hopes to become a leading dairy farmer in Ndunyu Njeru.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca C. is 56 years old and married with three adult children. She is from the village of Bitibut, Sapang Dalaga. To make a living, Rebecca sells snacks in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for 13 years and earns a monthly net income of 1,600 PHP.

In 2004, Rebecca joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Rebecca has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials needed to make her snacks. For her 14th loan, Rebecca is requesting 3,000 PHP, which will be used as additional working capital for the business.  

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional capital for snack vending business

loans.name: Rona

texts.en:
Rona M. is from the village of Poblacion, Sibutad. She is 44 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rona  raises hogs. Rona has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rona joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Rona is requesting her second loan of 3,500 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for hog raising.  

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional capital for hog raising

loans.name: Amina Jerotich

texts.en:
Amina Jerotich M. is forty nine years old, married and a mother of four children.  However two of her children are over twenty five years and hence she does not provide for them.  She only provides for two of her children.  Amina operates a retail shop in Kibomet in Kitale town, she has been in this business for one year now and gets a monthly income of ten thousand shillings.

This will be Amina's first loan from KADET LTD and he will use the loan to buy 20 bags of beans worth Kshs. 55,000, 10 bags of dry maize worth Kshs. 10,000, with the income she is going to get she plans to add more stock in her shop. In the future she wants to educate her children and also raise their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy cereals like beans, maize, etc.

loans.name: Burulbu's Group

texts.en:
Burulbu T. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Karabalta, a small town near Bishkek, the capital of Kyrgyzstan. She is 57 and married to a security guard. Together they have raised four sons and a daughter, and all the children are working.  

Burulbu is engaged in cattle breeding. Selling milk, she earns 2,400 KGS per month. With money from the loan, she wants to purchase a calf for breeding. In the future Burulbu wants to see all her children married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma M. is 49 years old and married with three adult children. She is from the village of Casul, Sapang Dalaga. 

To make a living, Elma is engaged in farming, and she sells assorted crops from her farm. From this activity, she is able to earn a monthly net income of 4,000 PHP. She has been in her business for 10 years.

In 2007, Elma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Elma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase farm supplies. Elma is requesting her third loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for her business.  

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita T. is from the village of D'Ban, Calamba. She is 51 years old, married and blessed with five children. 

Anita is engaged in running a grocery store, selling basic household items in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for 12 years and earns a monthly net income of 2,500 PHP.

In 2008, Anita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Anita is requesting her first loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for her business.  

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional capital for her grocery store

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica Odhiambo is married to John and they have four children; Murebith,Govan,Benson and Elvis who are all between the ages of 10 years and 18 years old.

Monica has a salon that she has been running for the past 11 years and is applying for her fourth loan from KADET LTD. She has a good credit history with KADET, as she has been paying back her loans well and in good time. She is in dire need of hair chemicals and hair piece for plaiting (type of hair style) her client's hair. She normally makes a profit of Kshs. 15,000 per month which is mainly used in paying school fees for her school going children. 

Her dream is to one day be able to own a big salon and open others in the neighbouring towns.

loans.use: Buy hair chemicals for treating hair and buy hair piece for plaiting

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a piece of land in good condition for building a house.

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita O. is 59 years old, married and has seven adult children. She is from the village of Poblacion, Sapang Dalaga. To make a living, Perlita runs a grocery store, selling basic household items in the local community. She has been in her business for five months and earns a monthly income of 2,300php.

In 2010, Perlita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perlita is requesting her first loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for the business.  

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for the store

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
Emelyn T. is from the village of Sinian, Cobungan. She is 34 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Emelyn owns and operates a business venture in the food sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling of fresh ocean-caught fish in the local community. Emelyn has been engaged in her business for more than 12 years and earns approximately 3,100 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2004, Emelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing materials. Emelyn is requesting fourth loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for the business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for the business

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
To make a living, Marilyn G. is engaged in the agriculture sector, particularly in growing crops to sell. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of her income is from selling of weaved "nipa" palm leaves for native roofs. She has been engaged in her business for 10 years and earns a monthly net income of 3500.00. Marilyn is 41 years old, married and blessed with one school-aged child. She is from the village of Dioyo, Sapang Dalaga. 

In 2007, Marilyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,850 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used for personal purposes. Marilyn is requesting her 7th loan of 7,500 PHP which will be used for medical purposes.  
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For medical purposes

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinter A. is 32 years old and married to Peter Otieno and they have four children aged between 11 years and three years old.

Jacinter has a retail shop that she runs in Molem shopping centre and has created a huge clientelle due to the fact that her shop is strategically placed. Jacinter needs money to buy maize, sugar, and cooking oil to add to her stock to enable her meet the demands of her clients. She is currently applying for her first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a friend of hers who is a client. The profits made will be used to cater for the family needs and also pay school fees for her children.

Her desire is to own a big supermarket in the future and sell things on wholesale price.

loans.use: Buy maize, sugar and cooking oil

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn L. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao. She is 33 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector growing assorted crops to sell. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 2009, Evelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase housing materials. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Evelyn from PMPC. 
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house repair

loans.name: Tynar's Group

texts.en:
Tynar J., 51, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Karabalta, a small town near to Bishkek (capital of Kyrgyzstan). Unfortunately, she is a widow. She has raised three sons and a daughter. All the children, except the youngest son, are married and live separately with their families. In order to earn money Tynar breeds cattle and sells milk. She earns 2000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase household appliances in order to improve her living conditions. In the future, she wants to see her youngest son get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase household appliances

loans.name: Mean

texts.en: Twenty-two year old Mean C. sews clothing in the garment industry. Mean C. has been working at her job since 2009 and has a salary. Besides that,  Mean C. is also a local farmer. The harvest season is coming, and she is concerned that she will face difficulties in picking up her rice to stock in her house. Mean C. has asked for a loan of $500 to buy a trailer to connect to her existing motorcycle. She will use it to pick up her rice to stock.  Her husband works as a driver in the garment factory in Phnom Penh City. The couple helps each other to earn money to feed their school-aged child.

loans.use: To buy a trailer to connect to the existing motorcycle for picking up her rice.

loans.name: Jhonna

texts.en:
Jhonna A. is 28 years old, married, and has three young children. She is from the village of Bunawan, Calamba. To make a living, Jhonna is engaged in the clothing sector, specifically in selling RTW's (ready-to-wear items). She has been engaged in her business for 2 years and earns a monthly net income of 2300.00.
 
In 2009, Jhonna joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jhonna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase home appliances. Jhonna is requesting a 4th loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase new stock to sell. 
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase stock

loans.name: Kulpari's Group

texts.en:
Kulpari S., 53, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Karabalta, a small town near to Bishkek (capital of Kyrgyzstan). Unfortunately, she is a widow.  She has raised four daughters and two sons. Most of the children are married and employed, and the youngest son studies at school. Ten years ago, with an initial investment of 5000 soms,  Kulpari started to provide sewing services. She sews Kyrgyz national cloth, pillows and blankets. In this way, she earns 12000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to purchase cattle for breeding. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a calf in order to increase her cattle stock.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf

loans.name: Trinidad

texts.en:
Trinidad O. is from the village of Calaran, Calamba. She is 48 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Trinidad owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector growing rice to sell. The main source of income for the business comes from selling of assorted crops from her own farm. Trinidad has been engaged in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month for these activities. 

In 1999, Trinidad joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Trinidad has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Trinidad is requesting a new loan of 14,500 PHP, which will be used for house repair. This loan will be the 19th loan taken out by Trinidad from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house repair

loans.name: Nurjamal's Group

texts.en:
Nurjamal J. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Karabalta, a small town near Bishkek (capital of Kyrgyzstan).  She is 37 and married to a construction worker. She has two sons and a daughter. The first son and the daughter attend school and the second son is preschool age (under seven). In order to earn money to cover family expenses, Nurjamal breeds livestock and sells milk. In this way she earns 2,800 KGS per month. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase coal for heating during the winter season. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase coal

loans.name: Tang

texts.en: Tang B. is strongly skilled at building stone and wooden houses. He has a few physical laborers to help provide his service. He receives a lot of orders from his clients to construct their houses. He wife sells gasoline in the local market, Kompong Chhnang province. Tang B. has two children, all of whom are students and dependent on him. Currently, his wife's business is the profitable one in the family, and now she wants to invest more capital to buy more gasoline to stock. She will sell it when the price increases. That is why Tang B. has decided to ask for a loan from lenders on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase gasoline for future sales while the price is low

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en:
Romeo A. is from the village of Sta. Filomena. He is 64 years old, single, and has no children. Romeo operates a family member's business, a radiator shop in the local community. He has been engaged in this business for over 41 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Romeo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to purchase materials for his shop. Romeo is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional accessories and equipment for his shop. This will be the 24th loan taken out by Romeo from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his family's general living conditions.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase accessories and additional equipment

loans.name: Fredrick Kibet

texts.en:
Fredrick Kibet L. is a 37 year old man, married to Salome Jerotich and together they have two children.  Salome is a business lady in Kitale, and Fredrick has several business such as a hardware shop, retail shop, butchery.  He has been in these business for ten years now and he gets a monthly income of fifteen thousand shillings. 

This will be fredrick's first loan from KADET LTD, and he intends to add more stock to the retail shop mostly food commodities like sugar, cooking fat, maizeflour, etc. 

With the income that he will get from the business he plans to further diversify his businesses and start dairy farming. In future he wants to educate his children in the best school in Kitale and also buy land and build rental houses which will add to his income.

loans.use: To buy food commodities for resale

loans.name: John Ole

texts.en:
John, 24 years old of age has practiced livestock farming in Naivasha town for the last two years.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy five cows which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

In future, John hopes to practice large scale zero grazing and become a leading supplier of animals products in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy five cows which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Daniel Ole

texts.en:
Daniel Ole K. is a 25 year old, married to Hellen, and is blessed with three children.  Daniel is a farmer and he has been doing this for the last six years. His farm is in a productive area which has proven to be good for maize farming.

He learned about KADET LTD through a marketing campaign done by KADET staffs in his area of residence. This will be his second loan, which he is planning to buy maize seeds and fertilizers. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to increase his maize production and educate his children.

His hopes and dreams is to become a large scale farmer and buy a bigger piece of land and build a permanent home.  Daniel is a diligent man who can do more if supported financially

loans.use: to buy maize seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Nche

texts.en:
G. was born in 1970. She is married to Nche Michael Nji and they are blessed with five children. She and her family share five rooms in Ndamukong, a quarter of Bamenda in the North West Region of Cameroon. G. has had great difficulties in her life, such as ill-health, failure to attain quality education and the sudden death of her sister-in-law which led to the adoption of a 5-day-old child. Amongst other challenges, she needs more capital to be able to continue with her projects and personal life.

With this loan, G. plans to cultivate maize, beans, yams, cassavas, and huckleberries. She also intends to buy improved maize seeds and yams for her farm plot and stock petrol and firewood to sell. The loan will help her community because they will be able to buy petrol and firewood at affordable quantities and prices. G. will reinvest her profit into her business and use a fraction of it to pay for her children's education and upgrade her standard of living. She prefers a loan from GHAPE because of the training she frequently receives, the follow-up and the moderate interest rate. ABOUT GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy seeds, seedlings, firewood and petrol

loans.name: Kulpunay

texts.en:
Kulpunay S. is 39-year-old attentive mother of four children. She has higher pedagogical education and works as a teacher of Russian language and literature at the local school. Her husband works as a policeman. Unfortunately, Kulpunay and her husband's wages are too low to cover all of their household's expenses. In order to find an additional means of subsistence for her family, Kulpunay decided to start her own business reselling goods.

With an initial capital of 20,000 KGS, Kulpunay began to sell women’s clothing and outer garments. Her start as an entrepreneur was successful due to strong efforts, which led Kulpunay to broaden her business by selling different kinds of fabrics. Her loyal customers were attracted by the high quality of goods and Kulpunay's cheerfulness.

In June 2010, when violent clashes broke out in the city of Osh, Kulpunay lost her business, which was robbed and looted. However, Kulpunay hasn’t given up and is ready to resume her lost business and continue working. Therefore, Kulpunay is applying for a loan of 100,000 KGS to restart her business. She plans to rent a space in the local market to sell women’s clothing and fabrics. Kulpunay’s motivation is really strong because she is eager to see her children educated and successful.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase women’s clothing and fabrics for resale

loans.name: Ou

texts.en: Ou T., 62, is a professional cleaner who started her work nine years ago. She works at the local hospital and earns a stable salary of US $2 each day. She was married, but her husband died of old age. She has three children who work in the garment industry. Ou T. has been building a bathroom but it is still not complete because she doesn't have enough savings. Ou T. is requesting a US $500 loan to be used to continue building her bathroom.

loans.use: to continue building her bathroom

loans.name: Wattuba Aids Group-Kampala

texts.en: S. Umaruh, 38 years old, belongs to the Wattuba Aids group, Kampala. He has been operating his general store in Kiti B Trading Center for 4 years. He says he began this business immediately after he finished constructing a commercial plaza in Kiti. Prior to this, he was mostly into coffee selling and real estate. Umaruh, a happily married father of 5, says this business generates him 70,000 UGX weekly. He also has a side business of commercial motorcycle transportation. With this loan, Umaruh is going to purchase more retail commodities such as sugar, salt, soap and soft drinks to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more items to resell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 47-year-old married man living with his wife and two young school-age children. He is from Lebanon. He has been working as a perfume vendor from his house for more than 10 years. In parallel, he's been working as an agent for a local company since 2007. He is the only financial support for his family. It is frequent in Lebanon to have multiple jobs to handle family expenses. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $700 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase additional perfumes and cosmetics products so he can increase his sales and income. In the future, he is planning to open a perfume and gadgets shop.

loans.use: To purchase additional perfumes and cosmetics products

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson, age 24, is a single young man who lives in a place called Kirigu in Kikuyu town which is on the outskirts of Nairobi town. He sells phone accessories and has been operating this business for the last seven years. 
This is his second loan from KADET and he intends to use it to buy more phone accessories and expand his trade.  If the loan improves the business, he will open other outlets in Kikuyu town.

loans.use: Benson wants to buy more phones accessories.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 23-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and five siblings. He worked in a butcher shop starting in 1999 and now owns a butcher shop after having gained the needed experience in the field. He is the only income source for his family. With his first Kiva loan, he was an excellent client making payments on time.

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner Ameen s.a.l., to improve his business by getting new machinery and adding new decorations for his shop. He wants to attract more customers, who are asking for good, clean, fresh meat.

loans.use: To improve his business

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan S. is 48 years old and a basket weaver and seller. She has been selling her woven bamboo baskets since early 2007. She normally earns US $2.50 per day to feed her family. She is married and has three children, all of whom are no longer in school. One of her children works for a bread company and the other two are basket makers. Her husband stays at home to help braid the baskets. As the harvest season is coming, Chan S. will use her loan to purchase more rice to stock for selling and eating. She hopes to use the rest of this loan to care for her ill elderly mother.

loans.use: to purchase more rice to sell and to eat

loans.name: Genalin

texts.en:
Genalin G. is from the village of Sta. Filomena. She is 31 years old, married, and has 4 school aged children. Genalin operates a family member's business, making and selling peanut butter in the local community. She has been engaged in this business for 1 year and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Genalin joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to purchase raw materials for her business. Genalin is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase peanuts, containers and other ingredients for her peanut butter business. This will be the 15th loan taken out by Genalin from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase peanuts, containers and other ingredients

loans.name: John Mokato

texts.en:
John Makato P. is 26 years old, married to Mary P., and is a father of three who all are schooling.  John is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for the last fifteen years.

He learned about KADET LTD from credit officers in their adverse marketing. This will be his first loan, which he plans to spend to purchase farm inputs. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

John hopes to practice large scale farming and attain financial independence. He is a hard working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is an 18-year-old single man living with his parents and four siblings. He is from Lebanon. He has been working as a concrete carpenter for more than five years. In 2008, he started to work as a freelance carpenter for different construction projects. He works with his father and one brother to keep the family’s financial status in good shape. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase some wood so he can enlarge his business by increasing his income.

loans.use: To purchase some wood for his work

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel C. became a Solio agent in November; enabling him to lease solar chargers to ten members of his community.  So far, Daniel is enjoying his Solio products. His children are able to study for longer periods during the night from the Solio generated environmentally friendly light. The radio powered by the Solio has better reception than the one he was using before and he enjoys using it. Having the Solio has also raised his social status within the community from a mere Fundi to a man of Stima. Economically, Daniel has already started to save money by using the Solio as he no longer needs paraffin (kerosene lamp), batteries for a radio, or a torch and can now charge his own phone. Solio is Daniel’s first loan from Kadet.

loans.use: To purchase and resell solar powered products

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy M. is 34 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. Joy has a retail shop business, which she has run for less than a year.
To help expand her business, Joy has requested a loan of 1,600,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase sugar, bread and soda. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Joy hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Joy hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, bread and soda for resale

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
N. Ruth, 42 years old, has been running a poultry business for 4 years in Walukuba-Jinja. The widowed Ruth says she took over this business immediately after her husband's demise. She and her husband had 4 children together.

Ruth has mostly been selling broiler chickens, which are in high demand, especially in the many trading centers around Jinja. To make headway in this business, Ruth has had to summon up a lot of perseverance. She also runs an outside catering business. The business generates 300,000 UGX monthly, and with this loan, Ruth is going to buy more broilers to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more broilers for resale

loans.name: Risa Ole

texts.en:
Risa has practiced livestock farming in Naivasha town for the last five years.  When not herding, he is at the market center selling maasai traditional clothes.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his first loan which he plans to buy 20 sheeps which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

In future, Risa hopes to be a large supplier of animal products in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy 20 sheep which he will rear and sell later at a profit.

loans.name: Samjella

texts.en:
Samjella E. F. was born in 1967. He is married and the father of four children, all below the age of 15. He and his family share three rooms in Njianga Quarters, in Nsongwa village mile 90 Bamenda, North West Region, Cameroon.

E. has encountered a lot of difficulties in life, the most profound being the death of his parents while he was still very young. As a result, he was unable to educate himself nor to have three square meals a day. Ill health has also been one of his problems. He has been unable to have good medical treatment because he has no money. Since he has joined GHAPE, he has seen the following changes in his life: sending his children to school, affording three square meals a day for his family, encouraging capital for his business and paying his hospital bills without a lot of difficulty.

With this loan of 200,000 XAF, E. will increase his capital and buy farm tools, piglets and pig feed. The manure from the pigs will be used to farm vegetables, some of which he will sell. His community and family will benefit from the vegetables, manure and meat when the pigs are edible. His activity will help reduce distance from members of his community and will be available at all times. E. says, “My children will all be well educated.” He will use the profit from his business to educate his children, increase his capital and provide basic needs for himself and for his family. He prefers GHAPE because of the training and follow-up he frequently receives. He appreciates that GHAPE does not ask for collateral securities and that it provides low cost loans, with gradual payments. About GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy farm tools, piglets and pig feed

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary C. became a Solio agent in November; enabling her to lease solar chargers to 10 members of her community. Mary has received good appraisals of the Solio from her family members and the Solio clients in the area. Mary invests the weekly reactivation fees in her business, which is increasing her profits so that she can repay her loan back to Kadet. She is enjoying her Solio and the benefits of charging her own phone herself, which gave her a lot of problems before. Mary’s reputation within the community has increased as she is now known as ‘Mama Stima’. Her children enjoy using Solio to read and socialize, a big change from complaining about the dark and going to bed early. Solio is Mary’s second loan from Kadet.

loans.use: To buy solar powered products for leasing to other customers

loans.name: Eddie

texts.en:
Eddie O. is 25 years old and lives in the town of Pallisa in the Iganga region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. Eddie has a phone accessories shop, which he has run for less than a year.
To help expand his business, Eddie has requested a loan of 1,600,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more phone accessories. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Eddie hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, he hopes to own another house.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories for resale

loans.name: Iyad

texts.en:
Iyad A. S. is married and the father of two daughters and two sons. He is a National Palestinian Authority employee and lives in Jabalia Refugee Camp in the Gaza Strip.

Iyad’s children are still young and studying at the elementary school. He feels that now that his daughters are growing up, they need to have their own room. Iyad came to FATEN and is requesting a loan to furnish his daughters’ room.

loans.use: To purchase bedroom furniture for his daughters

loans.name: Nelson Kariuki

texts.en:
Nelson has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru for the last 15 years. He is 55 years old and married to Lucy Wanjiku.

Nelson was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our field officers and this will be his second loan. He repaid his previous loan of 40,000 KES well and in good time. He plans to use this loan to plant potatoes this season. In the future, Nelson hopes to expand his farming and practice large scale farming.

loans.use: to plant potatoes

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 48-year-old married man living with his wife and one child, who is attending school. He's been working as a brick cleaner for 25 years. In 1990, he decided to work on his own, offering floor polishing to customers. He works closely with many construction projects and individual jobs to handle his family’s expenses. He works in cooperation with his wife, who has been a tailor since 2006. He obtained a first Kiva loan and, during the loan cycle, there was a health event in the family and, despite the situation, he was able to pay all his bills successfully. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $700 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase essential tools to make his work much easier and cleaner.

loans.use: To purchase essential tools

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng V. D. is a 31-year-old rural villager living in Kompong Cham Province. She makes a living by sewing in a garment factory and earns a fixed salary to contribute to the family’s expenses. Her husband is a construction worker in a mobile village and he earns about $3.50 each day. The couple has three children, all of whom are single and studying at school. Heng V. D. would like a loan of $1,000 in order to purchase a piece of land in good condition for a farming business.

loans.use: to purchase a piece of land to farm

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Wobulezi in the Luweero region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Robinah has a business of a pig production, which she has had for less than one year.  She has a second business of a retail shop  

To help expand her business, Robinah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase pig feeds and sugar.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Robinah hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Robinah hopes to own a whole sell shop.        Robinah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and sugar

loans.name: Kitita

texts.en:
Kitita K. is 45 years old. His wife is named Maria and together they are blessed with six children. Kitita is a farmer, and he has been doing this for the last three years. His farm is in a productive area that has proved to be good for maize farming.

He learnt about KADET LTD through a marketing campaign by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his second loan, which he is planning to use to buy maize seeds and fertilizers. He hopes to use the profits from this loan to acquire more land for farming, so that he can increase his maize production and educate his children.

His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer, buy a bigger piece of land, and build a permanent home. Kitita is a rigorous man who can achieve more if supported financially.

loans.use: To buy maize seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 50-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and five school-age children. He has owned his small grocery store since 2001. He offers food products, dairy products, detergents etc. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional products for his shop to increase his products variety, which will satisfy his customer’s needs and therefore his family's profits. In the future, he expects that his business will continue to grow in the coming year. 

It is very common in Lebanon to find small supermarkets selling perishable and non-perishable goods. As members of the communities themselves, storeowners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demands. The strong network of community relationships are an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in smaller towns and villages.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for his shop

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: T. Harriet, 61 years old, says her 8 year poultry business was an enterprise she began on a small scale. The business, which she has been operating from Nizam-Jinja, has grown by leaps and bounds, given Harriet's hard work. She says she was more inclined to farming before she took up this business. Like most single women in Uganda, Harriet works hard, bearing in mind the societal odds stacked against enterprising women like her. She mostly sells layer chickens and eggs. This business generates 350,000 UGX monthly for her. With this loan, Harriet is going to buy more layer chickens to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more layer chickens to resell

loans.name: Kol

texts.en: Kol S. is a 40 year old married mother who currently lives in the best territory of Phnom Penh Capital, in Cambodia. She is a local chef who is always hired by neighbors to cook meals for their wedding parties and their other ceremonies, while her husband works repairing cars. The family includes three devoted children, three of whom are single. Two of their children are employed in different jobs. Currently, Kol S. is not comfortable, because her house often needs to be repaired. She would like a loan to repair her old house.

loans.use: To repair her old house.

loans.name: Parsapiyio Ole

texts.en:
Parsapiyio Ole K. is 61 years old. He is married and supports sixteen people in the family.

Parsapiyio has been a farmer for twenty years. His farm is in a productive area that has proved to be good for wheat farming.

He learnt about KADET LTD through a marketing campaign by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his second loan, which he is planning to use to buy seed wheat and fertilizers. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming, so that he can increase his wheat production and educate his children.

In the future he wants to practice large-scale farming, and later, when the business is stable, he also plans to buy a bigger piece of land where he can build a permanent home and settle his family. Parsapiyio is a hardworking man who is capable of achieving more if supported financially

loans.use: To buy seed wheat and fertilizers.

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en: Chantal sells vegetables. She is 28 years old, married and has two children. None of her children are enrolled in school. Her husband works as a mechanic. Chantal needs this loan to buy more eggplants and carrots to sell. She says that she has spent eight years in this business. She hopes to build a house from the profits she makes and feels as if she can achieve even more than what she has done already.

loans.use: To add more eggplants and carrots to sell.

loans.name: Immaculee

texts.en: Immaculee owns a business of selling women's clothes. She has been doing this for twelve years. She is 28 years old, married, and has three children who are between one and six years old. She also cares for three sisters and the children all attend school. Immaculee sells women's clothes, which is why she decided to request a new loan to add to and upgrade her business. She will build her own home instead of renting with the new profits generated from this loan. She would wish to have more sales to suppliers in the future.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en: Beatha is 30 years old, married and has two children. All her children go to school. Her husband is also a businessperson who sells shoes. Beatha sells clothes especially for women; she has been doing this business for eight years. Beatha needs this loan to buy more clothes and she hopes to reinvest the profits she anticipates in the growth of her business. She dreams of becoming a supplier of clothes in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Rosette

texts.en: Rosette is 34 years old, married and has eight children who are between seven months and fifteen years old. Currently, six of her children attend school.  Rosette sells clothes, which she has done for seven years. Her husband is a carpenter.  Rosette will use the loan to purchase more clothes to sell.  With the new profits from her expanded business, Rosette plans to refurbish her house.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Mpabuka

texts.en: Mpabuka is 28 years old, and married, his wife is currently studying. They have two children who are between two and five years old. All the children attend school. Mpabuka sells used shoes; he has been in this business of shoes for ten years. He praises his business that has done a lot like paying school fees for his children and rental payments. He decided to request this loan to buy more shoes to sell. He would like to make savings from the anticipated profits of his business. He wishes to prosper in his business career in the future.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to sell.

loans.name: Claire

texts.en: Claire owns a beauty products shop. She is 40 years old, and divorced. She has three children who are enrolled in school. She says that her business has done tremendous things and allowed her to purchase things like a TV set, refrigerator, pay school fees and much more. Therefore, she was inspired to request a new loan to add more beauty products in her shop. With the profits from this business she will reinvest. In the future, she has zeal to create a cooperative of a large number of people for a better working environment.

loans.use: To buy more beauty products to sell.

loans.name: Triphine

texts.en: Triphine sells charcoal and she has been doing this business for a period of seventeen years. Triphine is 40 years old, married to a driver, and has four children, including twins, who are between ten and fifteen years old, and two other dependents she cares for. All her children go to school. She would need to get this new loan to buy more charcoal to sell. After loan repayments, with the profits that will be obtained, she plans to repair and renovate her house. She dreams of having two stocks of charcoal in years to come.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en: Clementine is 30 years old. She is married with one child who is two months old. Her husband works as a taxi driver. Clementine sells foodstuffs and she has spent three years in this business. She hopes to use this new loan to buy more foodstuffs to sell. She would like to buy a truck from the profits she hopes to get from this loan. Clementine plans to save money and pay school fees for her children in the future.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Valentine

texts.en: Valentine sells vegetables. She is 22 years old, and married with two children who are between one and five years old. One of her children attends school. Her husband works as a bartender. Valentine has been in this business of selling vegetables for eight years. With this loan, she will add more vegetables such as tomatoes and carrots to sell. Valentine hopes to build a house from the profits and to continue paying school fees for her children in the future.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Marceline

texts.en: Marceline owns a business of used clothes. She is 24 years old, married and has two children between three and five years old. She cares for her young sister and all of them go to school. Her husband works as a jewelry dealer. Marceline has been selling clothes for two years.  For further expansion of her business, she decided to request a loan to add a variety of clothes to sell. She will re-invest in her business the profits that will be obtained and she would like to export clothes.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Marie Claire

texts.en: Marie Claire is 28 years old, married and has two children who are between one and three years old. None of her children have enrolled in school. Her husband operates as an electricity company technician. Currently, Marie Claire sells power and she has done this business for two years. She requested this loan to open up another business of hardware and she hopes to do more business related activities from the profits that will be generated. She dreams of having a big hardware store in the future.

loans.use: To set up a hardware business with this new loan.

loans.name: Pascasie

texts.en: Pascasie owns a business that sells boutique items. She is 32 years old, married and has four children who are between four and nine years old. Her husband works as a constructor. Pascasie has been selling boutique items for four years. Her loan will be used to add more foodstuffs and cooking oil in her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to renovate her house. In the future, she would like to increase the loan amount for better business turnover.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell.

loans.name: Jeaninne

texts.en: Jeaninne owns a business that sells cooking oil, sugar, and rice. She is 23 years old, married and has two children whom she cares for. Her husband sells clothes. Jeannine has been selling boutique items for one and a half years. Her loan will be used to buy sugar, rice, and cooking oil. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest and continue to grow her store.

loans.use: To buy more oil, sugar and rice

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a washing machine and stove

loans.name: Zibiya

texts.en: Zibiya is 36 years old, married and has six children. Currently, three of her children attend school. Zibiya sells vegetables, which she has done for eight years. Her husband is a carpenter. Zibiya will use the loan to purchase a variety of vegetables to sell.  With the new profits from her expanded business, Zibiya plans to build a house. She dreams of becoming a supplier of vegetables in the future.

loans.use: To add more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Twenty-eight year old Nicholas K. has been in the motorcycle transportation business for the past decade. He mainly operates from Amber Court near Jinja town. He says his brother played a leading role in influencing him to take up the idea of operating this business. Before that he was mainly involved in odd jobs in and around his neighborhood.

Nicholas, who is happily married with 3 kids, says weekly he is able to make shillings 160,000 as profit. With this loan, he says he is going to purchase another motorcycle. He envisages improved financial circumstances for his business in the aftermath of purchasing another motorcycle.

loans.use: To purchase another motorcycle.

loans.name: Aloysuis

texts.en:
Aloysuis was born in 1975; he is happily married to Keimoh Sharon. At the moment he does not have a child. He shares two rooms with his wife in Banja, a quarter in the North West Region of Cameroon.

Aloysuis has had great difficulties in life; the ill health of his parents, and the inability to provide three square meals for himself and his parents  Amongst other challenges, he needs more capital to be able to expand and maintain his business and also take good care of his wife and children to be. With this loan, he plans to buy a new engine, shock absorbers, change the chain, and the battery. This will go a long way to solving the problem of maintenance, which was on a daily basis. This business will help his community by providing them with ready transport means, ease transportation of farm products to market and farm inputs to the farms, considering the poor state of the farm roads.

He will use his profit to repay his loan gradually and also save to buy a plot and construct a house for his family. He will use a fraction of the profit to upgrade his standard of living.
