They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa is a 48-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a food vending business. She lives in Aborlan, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her food vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000. Elsa is borrowing PHP 15,000 to continue to fund the operations of her business. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Elsa aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.use: To fund the operations of her food vending business

loans.name: Peou

texts.en: Peou V. is a hard-working man who has spent his life working at Modern Centre, at Takhmao City. He is an internal staff member. Peou V. has been working in this job since 2009 and has a formal salary. His wife is employed in this Centre as well. They always try their best to feed their three kids who are students in the local school. In the future, Peou V. wishes to open one small shop in his house by selling some items for his neighbors and other people who are passers-by in the village. Peou V. also faces a problem: his house is too old and not attractive to the customers. To solve this obstacle, Peou V. would like to request a loan to be used to decorate his house.

loans.use: To be used to decorate his house.

loans.name: Ma. Luz

texts.en:
Ma. Luz is a 60-year-old widow who supports her family by selling vegetables and spices. She lives in Aborlan, Palawan. Ma. Luz joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Luz has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000 to buy vegetables and spices to sell at the market to continue to save up for future family needs. Ma. Luz is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.use: To purchase vegetables and spices to sell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita is a married woman who lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by buying and selling vegetables. Her husband Hernanie F., who is 50 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities. They have two children who are 8 and 21 years old. Both children are currently going to school. Nenita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past seven loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nenita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 16,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her eighth loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital to continue to save up for her children's education. Nenita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.name: Khim's Group

texts.en:
Eight members make up the village bank loan. They are located in Anlong Ta Sek Leu village, Kandal province. This village loan selected, Mrs. Khim C., a 29-year-old married woman, as the village bank president. The members of this village will use their portions of the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Khim C. and her husband, Mr. Loeung Yoeun, are farmers who own a 1.20-hectare of land, which they use to cultivate rice and different vegetables to sell to support their family living. For this farm, Mrs. Khim C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to support her crops. Aside from farming, her husband also earns his living by driving an agri machine for a salary. They have two children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to support her crops.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 25 years old, married and supports her family by operating a business buying and selling livestock. She lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her buying and selling of livestock business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000. Marilyn is borrowing PHP 13,000 to fund operations.  This will be her seventh loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Marilyn aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie D. is from the village of Dalig Viejo. She is 48 years old. Josie is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Josie owns & operates a business planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables to sell. Josie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Josie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Josie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to pay for services to increase her crop yield. This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Josie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees for her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase her crop yield

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is a married woman who lives in Aborlan, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: motorcycle repair and a tricycle transport businesses. Her husband Aldemer, who is 38 years old, works as a tricycle driver to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 5 and 10 years old. Myrna joined NWTF-Project DunggA. in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project DunggA., Myrna has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy new equipment for the motorcycle repair shop so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Myrna is a DunggA. woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project DunggA. (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them DunggA. - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.use: To purchase new equipment for her shop

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mom K. works as a cleaning staff in the city of Phnom Penh. She has been in this business since 2005 and she always receives a monthly salary. Mom K. is married, but she divorced her husband many years go. Mom K. has a life partner in her brother-in-law who works as a construction worker in his community. Her brother-in-law always shares his profit with Mom K. to use for daily expense. Presently, he lacks some construction materials to provide his construction service. To help her brother-in-law, Mom K. would like to request a loan for him to buy bricks, cement, a shovel, and other construction supplies.

loans.use: To buy bricks, cement, a shovel, and other construction supplies.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is from the town of Plaridel. She is 44 years old. Wilma is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Wilma owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Wilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Wilma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her  family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
Visitacion P. is from the village of Dalig Viejo. She is 61 years old. Visitacion is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Visitacion owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising pigs. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Visitacion has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Visitacion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Visitacion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Visitacion is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the 12th loan taken out by Visitacion from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Jean has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jean joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Jean is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Jean from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Soeung

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeung R. is a villager who lives in Tuol Krang village in Kandal province.  She is 57 years old, and a farmer who owns a plot of land which she uses to cultivate spring onion for a living.  With this farm she faces a problem with insufficient money to start up her spring onion. She would like to ask for a loan to buy spring onions for planting. Her husband, Mr. Chhoch Chhum, is a house builder and he earns a small income to support his family. 

This couple has two childR. who are seamstresses in the garment factory. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy spring onions for planting.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita M. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 36 years old. Juanita is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Juanita owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Juanita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7,800 PHP a month for these activities.

Juanita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Juanita is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Juanita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Yoeung

texts.en:
Mr. Yoeung P. is 49 years old, and he is a villager who lives in Tuol Sala village in Kandal province. He and his wife, Mrs. Chroeng Phal, are farmers who own a plot of land which they use to cultivate rice for their family living. Mr. Yoeung P. would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, rice seeds, gasoline, and to pay for hire laborers to plow his farm. Aside from farming, Mr. Yoeung P.  also earns his living though fishing, where he earns a small income to support his family. 

This couple has five children; three of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory and the others attend the local school. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seeds, gasoline, and to pay for hire laborers to plow his farm.

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Wilma is just starting this business.

In 2002, Wilma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. 

Wilma is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her 10th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Maria Aida

texts.en:
Maria Aida is from the village of Sibula. She is 47 years old. Maria Aida is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling dried foods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2004, Maria Aida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Maria Aida is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 8th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Nou

texts.en:
Mrs. Nou N. was born in 1962, and she is a villager who lives in Chey Otdam village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Nguon Vall , are farmers who rent a plot of land to cultivate rice and lotus for a living. 

In order to support this farming, Mrs. Nou N. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and oils, and to pay hired laborers to help on the farm. Aside from farming, she also sells fish in the local village, where she earns a little income to help support her family. 

This couple has two children. One is a laborer and the other is a student in the local school. Nou's husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and oils, and to pay hired laborers to help on the farm.

loans.name: Vong's Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people make up this village bank loan. They are located in Preaek Samraong village in Kandal province. This village loan selected Mr. Vong T., 35 years old, as the village bank president. The members hope to increase their income and improve their familys' standard of living through this loan.
 
Mr. Vong T. is a security guard, receiving a small salary to support his famiL.. His wife, Mrs. Din SarO., is a congee and balut egg seller in the local village. (Congee: rice porridge - Balut: a nearL. developed chicken or duck embryo that is boiled and eaten in the shell)

Due to the fact that his wife's business has been doing well, and in order to increase their income to improve the famiL.’s situation, he is asking for a loan to buy more balut eggs and more rice to expand his wife's business activities. 
 
This couple is working hard to support their three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is attending a local school, and the youngest one is a year old.

loans.use: To buy more balut eggs and more rice to expand his wife business activities.

loans.name: Kik

texts.en:
Kik T. is a 35-year-old mother caring for seven children. All seven children are still living in the family home. Three of them are employed in different jobs.  Kik T. has been a farming businesswoman for a long time, and she can earn a daily profit of around $1 per day. 

She has a life partner in her husband, who is a seller of recycled goods; he buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler. Currently, Kik T.’s husband uses his bike for going around to buy used goods, such as leftover electricity wires, in and around his village. Because his bike is so old, he cannot pick up a big amount of his product at once. To assist her husband, Kik T. is looking for a loan for her husband to buy a used motorcycle for picking up his items. 

Note: Kik T. and her husband and both shown in the picture.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle for picking up his items.

loans.name: Chea's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of five members who live in Ta Hing village in Kandal province. This group loan selected Mrs. Chea S.,who is 51 years old, as the group leader. With the loans, they hope to increase their income to improve their familys' standard of living. 

Mrs. Chea S. and her husband, Mr. Phon Phoeun, are farmers who own a plot of land that they use to cultivate peanuts to sell to support their family. However, they do not have enough money to continue farming. So, Mrs. Chea S. decided to ask for a loan to buy peanut seeds for cultivating. 

This couple has four children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory while the other three are students and also support their parents' farming.

loans.use: To buy peanut seeds for cultivating.

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Lay S. O. is a 42-year-old mother who has given birth to two children, both of whom are single and still living under her management. Her husband is a local farmer, earning an average income of $2 a day. 

Lay S. O. is a domestic rice trader. She buys rice in bulk from people who live in the village, and then she stores the rice in her stock supply in order to sell it later and gain a profit. 

Due to the fact that the rice harvesting season is coming, she has decided to seek a loan from Kiva for capital to buy more rice during the time when rice is commanding its lowest price. Then she will sell it later when the price is increasing.

loans.use: To buy rice in bulk while prices are low, for future sales.

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol is from the town of Plaridel. She is 34 years old and married. To make a living, she owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $163 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Mirasol joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. 

Mirasol is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Daylin

texts.en:
Daylin A. is from the village of Mamanga Daku, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Daylin is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a butcher shop, butchering and selling a variety of meats in the local community. Daylin has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately $50 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Daylin joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 1st loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Vergie

texts.en:
Vergie I. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 39 years old. Vergie is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $375 a month for these activities.

In 2006, Vergie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. 

Vergie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 8th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina is from the village of Lagag, Sindangan, Zamboanga Del Norte. She is 39 years old and a group member with PMPC. Avelina is married and has three children, two of whom are students while the eldest is in Manila. To make a living, Avelina operates a business of selling vegetable snacks in the local community. Avelina has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $88 a month for these activities. 

In 2008, Avelina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital. This will be her 7th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en:
Alberta B. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 56 years old. Alberta is widowed and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she plants and harvests rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately $25 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Alberta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. 

Alberta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be her 4th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is from the town of Plaridel. She is 39 years old. Marilou is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a  fishing business, harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $175 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Marilou joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. 

Marilou is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora is a 40-year-old married who supports her family by operating a business of selling fruit. She lives in Aborlan, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2008 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $250. 

Nora is borrowing 10,000 PHP so that she can purchase a stock of fruits to sell. This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 7,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Nora aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of fruits to sell

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie M. is from the village of Dalig Viejo. She is 54 years old. Lanie is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $120 a month for these activities.

In 2006, Lanie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. 

Lanie is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 12th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina O. is from the village of Dalig Viejo. She is 61 years old. Marina is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a tailoring business, providing both general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Marina has been engaged in her business for over thirty-three years and earns approximately $80 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Marina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread. 

Marina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and sewing materials. This will be her 7th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics and sewing materials

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
50-year-old Sylvia K. is now twenty years down the road in her poultry business in Nizam-Jinja. She has mostly been selling eggs and layer chickens. It was initially her husband's business, but with time she took over from him. She has four kids with her husband. They also have a goat selling business. Before she embarked on this business, Sylvia was more occupied doing subsistence farming. 

She says this business generates her about $756 a month, and with this loan she says she is going to buy more layer chickens that she will eventually resell.

loans.use: To purchase more layer chicken to resell

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita A. is from the village of Camarag San Isidro. She is 46 years old. Nenita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she plants and harvests rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-two years and earns approximately $810 per harvest.

In 2010, Nenita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. 

Nenita is requesting a new loan of 27,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Men

texts.en:
Men S. is a 45-year-old married woman who lives in the province of Kompong Chhnang. She stays at home doing housework. Her daily activities are cooking a nice meal, cleaning house, washing clothes and managing other property in and around her house. While she is doing housework, her husband works as a policeman in the village, where he can earn an income around $4.40 a day. They have two children. One is married and the other one is single and employed at a garment factory as a sewing worker. 

Men S.’s child doesn’t have her own vehicle for going to work, and she always hires a motor taxi or walks. To solve this problem, Men S. will use her loan for her daughter to buy a used motorbike for riding to work.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike for riding to work

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is married with one teenage daughter. She sells women's underwear at the central market in Belaya Tserkov town. Her monthly income is about $1,530 and the net profit is around $510 per month.

Olena started her business ten years ago. He daughter was very sick and the family spent lots of money for her treatment. So, Olena bought a kiosk at the market, got some inventory and began her retail business. Her daughter’s disease progressed for several years and her husband left Olena. Being a very strong person, Olena continued to develop her business.

Today Olena owns three business locations. She uses one by herself and rents two locations to other starting entrepreneurs. Olena would like to increase her assortment and is requesting a 10,000 UAH loan. She hopes to receive additional income and will spend it for her family's needs. Olena lives with her daughter and second husband.

loans.use: to increase assortment

loans.name: Kanha

texts.en:
Mrs. Kanha P. is 25 years old and her husband, Mr. Sovannra Um, is 26 years old. They live in a suburb of Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2006 and have one young son.  

Kanha and her husband are tailors. She is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for commuting because she does not have her own transportation. She spends a lot of money to take motor taxis or remoques (motocycles with trailers on the back).

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Fely

texts.en:
Fely Y. is from the village of Bacnor East. She is 60 years old. Fely is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Fely runs a general store. Fely has been engaged in her business for more than 20 years and earns approximately 4,200 PHP a month.

In 2006, Fely joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Fely has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Fely is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This will be the ninth loan taken by Fely from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offerings

loans.name: Poch

texts.en:
Making baskets is a part of 50-year-old Poch R.’s daily routine. Poch R. buys raw materials to make baskets to sell at the market. She also buys baskets from other weavers at a reasonable price and resells them to gain additional income. 

Besides this job, she sells sugar in her community, Kompong Chhnang province. On average, she can generate an income of $4 each day. 

They are blessed with six children; five are single and one is married. Two of their kids are working overseas, in Thailand, earning a profit of about $100 per month. 

In order to earn an extra profit, Poch R. would like a loan to buy additional sugar for sale, and to buy rice to stock and sell when the price increases. She hopes that she will be able to use the rest of fund to replace her old cow.

loans.use: To buy additional sugar and rice for resale

loans.name: Oksana

texts.en:
Oksana P. is married with two children. She runs a small business selling wallpaper. Her store is located at the central market and attracts many people every day.

Oksana started this business 10 years ago. Hard work and persistence helped her to develop this business well. Today she has many repeat clients. Oksana's average profit is 8,000 UAH per month.

Oksana would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to purchase more inventory. Winter time is a high season for remodeling. So there is a high demand for items like wallpaper. She is hoping to increase her sales and spend additional income for her family's needs.

loans.use: To purchase more wallpaper inventory

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chorn S. is a villager who lives in Krapeu Ha village in Kandal province. She was born in 1955. She owns a food stall for selling food and cooked rice to support her living. She also earns her living by selling Khmer traditional cake. 

Her husband, Mr. Chan Thorn, is 58 years old and works as a construction worker. Together, they are able to earn some income to support their family. They have two children; one is a car driver and the other is a student.  

In order to support her businesses and increase her income, Mrs. Chorn S. would like to ask for a loan to buy more rice and food to sell.

loans.use: To buy more rice and food to sell

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong H. is 68 year-old widow who currently lives in the province of Kompong Chhnang. She no longer has a life partner because her husband died of senility many years ago. 

She earns her daily wage by making baskets at her home. She also buys baskets from other weavers at a reasonable price and resells them at a profit. She has five married children; most of them have their own houses and lives independently. As it is the harvest season, Kong H. is requesting a loan to buy rice both to resell and for her own consumption.

loans.use: buying rice for resale, and for personal consumption.

loans.name: Seng's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of fifteen members who are taking out a village bank loan; they are located in Sambuor village in Kandal province. This village loan selected Mrs. Seng Y., a 36 year-old married woman, as the village bank president. Each member of this village will use their money for different purposes. 

Mrs. Seng Y. is a farmer who owns a plot of land which she uses to cultivate rice for a living. She would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline for growing rice. Her husband, Mr. Net Thy, is a laborer who receives a small salary to support his family.
 
This couple is working very hard with their careers to support their three children; one of whom is a laborer and the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline for growing rice.

loans.name: Ol

texts.en:
Ol T. has spent her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparent when she single. She is now married and has four kids; three are single and one is married. Two of their children are employed in various occupations, and getting a proper salary every month. Her husband frequently works alongside her in the fields. 

Growing crops is an annual activity with which she has had great success. She is able to plant at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. Recently, an existing motorcycle of Ol T.’s child has broken down during use. Ol T. will use her loan to add to her savings for her child to buy a new motor in order to replace the broken one.

loans.use: To replace a motorcycle engine

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a young man from Idna next to Hebron city in Northern Palestine. Mahmoud has a degree in computer maintenance and programming. Mahmoud wanted to start his own project. He started an Internet cafe one year ago. Mahmoud shares with his father taking care of the family and covering the household expenses.

Mahmoud wanted to purchase more computers and do maintenance for the ones that are in the cafe already to ensure better performance and more customers. Mahmoud appears in the picture here in FATEN's office.

loans.use: To purchase computers and do maintenance on the current ones

loans.name: Nellevine Anyango

texts.en:
Nellevine Anyango W. is twenty three years old, married to Charles Onyango and together they have two beautiful children, her husband is also a business person. Nellevine operates general stores whereby she sells cereals as aprimary business, she also sells charcoal, and kerosene at the same time, in Huruma Estate in Eldoret Town. 

She has been in this business for five years and earns a monthly income of KSH.10,000.This will be Nellevine's first loan from  KADET LTD, and she plans to add more stock in her shop like; more cereals (e.g maize), beans charcoal, and kerosene for resale. 

With the income she is going to get she plans to complete building her house which is still under construction, also raise her family's living standard. In future she plans to expand her business and also stabilize her family.

loans.use: To add more  stock; add cereals like dry maize,beans; buy more charcoal,and keresene for sale

loans.name: Noy's Group

texts.en:
Sixteen group members are forming a village bank loan; they are located in Sambuor village in Kandal province. This group has selected Mr. Noy H., 52, as the village bank president. Each member will use their portion of the group loan for a different purpose.

Mr. Noy H. and his wife, Mrs. Kan HO., are farmers who own 2 hectares of land that they use to cultivate rice for a living. Mr. Noy H. would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides, and gasoline for cultivating rice.

This couple has two children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other is a barber.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides, and gasoline for cultivating rice.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John S. is 37 years old, married to Veronica Lepshoi and together they have two children.  His wife also contributes to bring in income to the family by keeping and selling poultry. They live in Ngenyilel in the outskirts of Eldoret town.

John sells milk in the area of his residence whereby he has good number of customers who buys milk on a daily basis from him. His monthly income is KES 9,000.

This will be John's second loan with KADET LTD, the first loan he repaid successfully, and he plans to use the loan he will get to support his business. In future John wants to be a milk wholesaler in Eldoret.

loans.use: To support his business by buying more milk for selling

loans.name: Razakan's Group

texts.en:
Razakan J. is the leader of this group. She is the resident of Toktogul. She is 50 and married. Her husband is engaged in cattle breeding. Together they are bringing up a daughter and two sons. The youngest son studies at school and the other children are employed.  

Razakan herself works as a teacher at school. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future Razakan wants to purchase a piece of land for farming.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (remaining environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Than's Group

texts.en: Sixteen members of this group have applied for a loan. All live in Sambuor village in Kandal province. Mrs. Than L., who is 35 years old and married to a police officer, has been chosen as group leader by the members, each of whom will use a portion of this loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Than L. earns her living by providing beautician services for weddings, and will use her portion of this loan to buy the clothing and supplies she needs to serve her customers. She and her husband plan to use the additional income made possible by this loan to support their three children, all of whom are in school.

loans.use: To buy clothes and supplies needed to run a small business.

loans.name: Divine Group

texts.fr: Badesire B.  est entrepreneur, présidente du groupe Divine,  âgée de 48 ans, veuve, mère de 6 enfants orphelins de père. En dépit de tout, ses enfants étudient confortablement.  Elle fait le petit commerce de vente de divers  dans un kiosque à son domicile. Elle  commença son business  avec son fonds propre. Elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF  Hekima de 50$ en 2004 lorsqu’elle travaillait avec le groupe Shangilieni.  Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouveaux articles (sucres, sel de cuisine, savons, bombons, allumettes, biscuits, etc.) pour augmenter le stock en volume et en valeurs. En plus, elle ambitionne  acheter une moto pour faire le taxi urbain. La cliente Badesire B.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions en faveur de pauvres exclus de banque classique. Il sied de signaler que le groupe Divine est composé de 33 membres.
texts.en: Badesire B.   is an entrepreneur, and president of the group Divine. She is 48 years old and mother of 6 fatherless children. In spite of their situation, her children continue their studies comfortably. She sells various products from a stall at her home. She started up her business with her own money. She received a loan of 50$ from the IMF Hekima in 2004 when she worked with the Shangilieni group. This new loan should allow her to buy new articles (sugar, cooking salt, soap, sweets, matches, biscuits etc.) to increase her stock in volume and value. In addition, she aims to purchase a motorbike in order to provide an urban taxi service. Badesire B.   would like to thank Hekima for their action in favour of the poor who are excluded from classic bank loans. It should be pointed out that the Divine group is made up of 33 members.

loans.use: purchase of sugar, cooking salt, sweets, matches, biscuits,etc.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Nomer

texts.en:
Nomer R. lives in the village of Samonte. He is 24 years old, single and makes a living by growing rice. He has been in this business for more than nine years and earns about 30,000 PHP for each harvest.

In 2010, Nomer joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He is applying for a new loan for 23,000 PHP to buy seeds and seedlings for his next crop. This loan is his first, and he plans to use the additional income it generates to support his family.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy seeds and seedlings for a new rice crop.

loans.name: Yeng's Group

texts.en: Sixteen residents of Sambuor village in Kandal province have applied for this group loan. The members have chosen Mrs. Yeng S., who is 47 years old, as their leader, and all plan to use a portion of this loan to improve the lives of their families. Mrs. Yeng S. and her husband are farmers who own two-hectare plot of land on which they grow rice. She will use her portion of this loan to buy fertilizer and fuel. Her husband works in construction, and the couple plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to support their two children, one of whom is a teacher while the other is still attending school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and fuel.

loans.name: Sulaika's Group

texts.en:
Sulaika T., 61, is treasurer of this four-person loan group. She lives in the town of Toktogul and is a widow who has raised six children. She receives a pension, but supplements her income by breeding livestock. She started her business 10 years ago with an initial investment of 10,000 soms, and now earns about 3,000 soms a month. With the money she earns from this loan, she plans to buy more cattle for breeding. Her goal is to continue expanding her business so that she can help her children support their families. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and watch a video about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy cattle for breeding

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo G. lives in the village of Victoria San Mateo. He is 59 years old, married and has one school-aged child. For more than 22 years he has made a living by growing rice, and earns about 30,000 PHP per harvest. 

In 2010, Alfredo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He is applying for a new loan of 27,000 PHP to buy seeds and seedlings to use in his next crop. This loan is his first from ASKI, and he plans to use the additional income he will earn to continue improving his farm.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy seeds and seedlings for a rice farm.

loans.name: Rodrigo's Group

texts.en:
Rodrigo C. is from the village of San Miguel Ramon. He is 55 years old. Rodrigo is the leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Rodrigo is married. To make a living, Rodrigo provides recycling services, hauling plastics and other recyclables for local businesses and community members. Rodrigo has been engaged in his business for more than 26 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

Rodrigo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. Rodrigo is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional plastics and other recyclables to sell. This will be the 12th loan taken out by Rodrigo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional recyclables to sell

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita G. is from the village of Brgy. Sta. Rosa, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 52 years old. Carmelita is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Carmelita runs a general store, selling food and daily use products in the local community. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for more than eight years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Carmelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Carmelita is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken by Carmelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa F. is from the village of Caluya, Sapang Dalaga. She is 50 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Teresa sells ready-to-wear clothing. Teresa has been engaged in her business for more than four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. 

In 2006, Teresa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Teresa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used for personal purposes. For her 15th loan, Teresa is requesting 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional stock to sell.
  
About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing to sell

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson G. K. is 23 years old and single. To earn a living, he sells vehicle spare parts. He has engaged in the business for the past three years. He was previously employed in a restaurant before he started his own business.  

He hopes to have a fully established business in the future. He has requested a loan of 50,000 KES to buy starters, alternators and wipers.

loans.use: To buy starters, alternators and wipers

loans.name: On

texts.en:
On P. is a smart woman who currently works as a manager in a hotel in Kompong Chhnang province. She has been working in this job since 2005, and she always get a fixed monthly salary. 

Besides her currently job, On P. sells a few products like food, soft drinks, shampoo and plastic products in her village. Right now, her selling business is going well, and she always has many customers who come to buy her products. 

On P. thinks that she may be able to earn more  income, so she wishes to invest more funds to purchase more items for sale. This is the reason why On P. has decided to borrow some funds from Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more items for selling such as food and soft drinks

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a laptop and a welding machine

loans.name: Merriam

texts.en:
Merriam P. is from the village of Bacnor East, Burgos, Isabela. She is 54 years old and married with two adult children. To make a living, Merriam owns a general store which she has had for over 17 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Merriam joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merriam has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Merriam is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Merriam from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated  to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: San

texts.en: Mrs. San R., born in 1978, is a villager who lives in K'am Samnar Leu village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Hean Kor, are farmers who own a two-hectare plot of land where they cultivate rice and corn to sell. Mrs. San R. would like a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline for their farm. They are working very hard to support their three children; two of whom attend the local school, and a four-year-old not yet in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline for their corn and rice farm.

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is 46 years old, married and a father of three. He owns a van which he uses for his transportation business. He was previously employed as a driver before he went into business. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has learnt how to manage his finances by saving his money. He hopes to own more vans and employ more people in the future. He needs a loan of 60, 000 Kes to buy tires for his van.

loans.use: To buy tires for his van

loans.name: Uk

texts.en: Uk L., age 36, makes a living by selling fish. She has been selling the fish that her husband catches or that she buys from other fisherman for over ten years. She currently earns an average of US$2 a day. Her husband is 37 years old and is a fisherman who works along a local river. Uk L. is the mother of four teenage children who are studying in school. Uk L. said that most of her fish are from her husband, but now his fishing materials are broken. To solve this problem, Uk L. would like to request a loan from Kiva for her husband to buy traps and other fishing equipment.

loans.use: To buy traps and other fishing equipment.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida B. is from the village of Camarag San Isidro, Isabela. She is 52 years old. Aida is married and has 3 grown children. To make a living, Aida owns & operates a business primarily planting and harvesting rice for sale. Aida has been engaged in her business for over 32 years and earns approximately 32000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Aida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Aida is requesting a new loan of 27000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Aida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Bonn

texts.en: Bonn is a member of Dea-Brothers group in Faulu Kenya. He runs "Young Blacks Engineering Works" for a living. He has been running the business for five years with two employees. He works hard in his business to provide a good education for his five-year-old child. He dreams of stabilizing his business in the future. He has requested for a loan of 50,000 KES to buy a refacing machine for the cylinder head.

loans.use: To buy a refacing machine for the cylinder head.
